factoid: The Massacre of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX’s will.
Charles IX gave the order for the Massacre of St. Bartholomew.
Charles IX thought the Massacre of St. Bartholomew was done as a result of his order.
The slaughter of eighty thousand men at Borodinó was due to Napoleon’s will.
Napoleon ordered the commencement of the battle at Borodinó.
Napoleon ordered the conduct of the battle at Borodinó.
Napoleon thought the slaughter at Borodinó was done because he ordered it.
Historic investigation confirms that the Massacre of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX’s will.
Historic investigation confirms that the slaughter at Borodinó was due to Napoleon’s will.
Napoleon shot at no one at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon killed no one at the battle of Borodinó.
The soldiers performed all killings at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon did not kill people at the battle of Borodinó.
The French soldiers at the battle of Borodinó went to kill and be killed by their own volition.
The French soldiers at the battle of Borodinó did not go to kill and be killed because of Napoleon’s orders.
The French, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutch soldiers were hungry, ragged, and weary of the campaign.
The French, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutch soldiers felt at the sight of an army blocking their road to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must be drunk.
If Napoleon had forbidden the soldiers to fight the Russians, the soldiers would have killed Napoleon.
If Napoleon had forbidden the soldiers to fight the Russians, the soldiers would have proceeded to fight the Russians.
The soldiers would have fought the Russians because it was inevitable.
The soldiers heard Napoleon’s proclamation offering them compensation for mutilation and death.
The soldiers heard Napoleon’s proclamation that they had been in the battle before Moscow.
The soldiers cried “Vive l’Empereur!” when they heard Napoleon’s proclamation.
The soldiers cried “Vive l’Empereur!” at the sight of the portrait of the boy piercing the terrestrial globe with a toy stick.
The soldiers would have cried “Vive l’Empereur!” at any nonsense that might be told them.
The soldiers had no choice but to cry “Vive l’Empereur!” and go to fight.
The soldiers went to fight in order to get food and rest as conquerors in Moscow.
The soldiers killed their fellow men not because of Napoleon’s commands.
Napoleon did not direct the course of the battle.
None of Napoleon’s orders were executed at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon did not know what was going on before him during the battle.
The killings at the battle of Borodinó were not decided by Napoleon’s will.
The killings at the battle of Borodinó occurred independently of Napoleon.
The killings at the battle of Borodinó occurred in accord with the will of hundreds of thousands of people who took part in the common action.
Napoleon thought that the battle took place by his will.
The question whether Napoleon had a cold has no more historic interest than the cold of the least of the transport soldiers.
Various writers asserted that Napoleon’s cold caused his dispositions to be not as well-planned as on former occasions.
Various writers asserted that Napoleon’s cold caused his orders during the battle to be not as good as previously.
The assertion that Napoleon’s cold caused his dispositions to be not well-planned is baseless.
The assertion that Napoleon’s cold caused his orders during the battle to be not as good is baseless.
Napoleon’s cold on the twenty‑sixth of August was unimportant.
The dispositions cited above were not worse than previous dispositions.
The dispositions cited above were even better than previous dispositions that led to victories.
Napoleon’s pseudo-orders during the battle were not worse than formerly.
Napoleon’s pseudo-orders during the battle were much the same as usual.
The dispositions and orders seem worse than previous ones because the battle of Borodinó was the first Napoleon did not win.
The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were a model of perfection.
The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were criticized for their perfection.
The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were criticized for their excessive minuteness.
Napoleon fulfilled his office as representative of authority at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon fulfilled his office as representative of authority at the battle of Borodinó better than at other battles.
Napoleon did nothing harmful to the progress of the battle at Borodinó.
Napoleon inclined to the most reasonable opinions at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon made no confusion at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon did not contradict himself at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon did not get frightened or run away from the field of battle at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon carried out his role of appearing to command calmly and with dignity at the battle of Borodinó.
Napoleon remarked “The chessmen are set up, the game will begin tomorrow!” after returning from a second inspection of the lines.
Napoleon ordered punch and summoned de Beausset.
Napoleon began to talk to de Beausset about Paris.
Napoleon began to talk to de Beausset about changes he meant to make in the Empress’ household.
Napoleon surprised the prefect by his memory of minute details relating to the court.
